offsets.text: We conducted a pragmatic cluster-randomised superiority trial in 8 general practices, with assessment of outcomes blinded to group allocation.
using a computer-generated randomisation schedule stratified by the number of FTE GPs within the practice (�8 versus >8 FTE).
An independent statistician at a central administra- tion site conducted the randomisation to ensure allocation concealment.
Practices and GPs were necessarily unblinded post randomisation to facilitate planning and delivery of intervention workshops and related data collection.

Recruited patients were unaware of the trial’s exis- tence and goals prior to presenting at their practice and were unaware that 2 different treat- ment approaches were being compared, meaning that they were masked to cluster allocation.
The primary patient-level outcome was disability at 6 months, measured with the Roland Mor- ris Disability Questionnaire (RMDQ; scale 0–24; higher scores indicate greater disability) [12].
The primary patient-level outcome was disability at 6 months, measured with the Roland Mor- ris Disability Questionnaire (RMDQ; scale 0–24; higher scores indicate greater disability) [12].
These patient-reported outcomes were collected at all patient follow-up points.
We conducted an intention-to-treat analysis in line with the statistical analysis plan included in the published protocol [11].
Sufficient data were available to include 98% of patient participants in primary outcome analysis.
Sufficient data were available to include 98% of patient participants in primary outcome analysis.
Sufficient data were available to include 98% of patient participants in primary outcome analysis.

Patient back pain related impairment measured with the Roland Morris Disability Questionnaire

Statistical significance will be judged with an a of  .  . All results will be reported as estimates of eﬀect size (e.g. mean diﬀerence, risk ratio, number needed to treat [NNT]) with   % confidence intervals (  % CI). All analyses will be conducted on an intention to treat basis.

Analyses will also account for clustering of data. For the patient-level outcomes, this clustering will be specified at the GP level – while randomisation is at the practice level. For the GP level outcomes, clustering will be specified at the practice level. The stratified nature of the randomisation schedule will be handled by including the practice size stratum identifier in analytical models (less than or equal to   FTE GPs, greater than   FTE GPs).

Primary patient outcome

The primary analysis will follow an intention to treat approach and compare mean RMDQ scores at  months between the intervention and control arms using a linear mixed model (adjusted for baseline RMDQ as a second fixed eﬀect). This model will also be adjusted for other factors known to aﬀect the outcome: age, gender, socioeconomic status, current back pain duration and nature (constant or episodic), receipt of recent or ongoing non-GP health care for back pain, previous history of back pain, baseline pain intensity, and baseline beliefs about back pain (self-eﬃcacy and expectation, fear avoidance). The analysis will also adjust for baseline HC-PAIRS scores as measured at the level of the GP (as a measure of baseline treatment competence). This adjustment will improve the precision of the intervention eﬀect estimate, and will also serve to improve handling of missing follow-up data.

A random eﬀect for GP will be used to account for the clustered nature of the data. Linear mixed models will be used to reduce bias due to incomplete follow-up: in this case, data from the  w,  w, and  m follow- up times will be included in the model when estimating diﬀerences at  m to allow for missing data at this final end point. The relative risk of a   % improvement in RMDQ scores will be reported, along with the numbers needed to treat (NNT) to achieve this target. As a sensitivity analysis, the NNT and RR of a  . point absolute reduction in RMDQ score will also be reported (in line with the absolute eﬀect size stipulated for the primary outcome).

Subgroup analysis will compare mean RMDQ scores at   months using the same model as the primary outcome for those who presented with a new episode of acute back pain of less than   weeks duration who had not received health care for back pain in the previous three months.
